snippet: A Central Saint Martins graduate teams up with a master craftsman in Jaipur, India, to make candy-colored jewels.
abstract: A Central Saint Martins graduate teams up with a master craftsman in Jaipur, India, to make candy-colored jewels.
lead_paragraph: Alice Cicolini, a London-based Central Saint Martins graduate, works with Kamal Meenakar, a master craftsman in Jaipur, India, on her candy-colored jewels. The pieces get their distinct finishes through champlevé, an intricate enameling process (called meenakari in India). "I'm drawn to enamel because it's like painting on precious metal," said Cicolini, whose latest creations incorporate exotic shapes and motifs associated with religious architecture found along the ancient Silk Road.
